title: Leonard Peters
text:
Leonard Peters (born December 26, 1981) is an <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="Safety%20%28American%20football%20position%29">safety</a> and a <a href="rugby%20union">rugby</a> player. He was originally signed by the <a href="New%20York%20Jets">New York Jets</a> as an <a href="undrafted%20free%20agent">undrafted free agent</a> in 2007 and was on the <a href="Chicago%20Bears">Chicago Bears</a> practice squad. He played <a href="college%20football">collegiately</a> at <a href="Hawaii%20Warriors%20football">Hawaii</a>. Peters performed as a Polynesian dancer in his native Hawai'i, which includes twirling flaming knives. He has also represented the <a href="USA%20Tomahawks">USA Tomahawks</a> in <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a>.
American Football Career.
College.
Peters played in 50 games for the <a href="University%20of%20Hawai%27i">University of Hawai'i</a> at safety, making 290 tackles, defending 20 passes, recording 7 interceptions and two sacks.
Professional.
Peters was signed to the <a href="Chicago%20Bears">Chicago Bears</a> practice squad on October 3, 2007. He was released by the Bears on August 30, 2008.
Move to Rugby union.
Peters has decided to move to <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>, a sport from which American football is derived. He was selected for the <a href="United%20States%20national%20rugby%20sevens%20team">US 7's</a> for the <a href="2009%20World%20Games">2009 World Games</a> in Taiwan. He showed well enough in the <a href="2009%20World%20Games">2009 World Games</a> to have been selected to the <a href="United%20States%20national%20rugby%20sevens%20team">USA Squad</a> for the first two legs of the 2009-10 <a href="IRB%20Sevens%20World%20Series">IRB Sevens World Series</a> to compete in Dubai and George, South Africa. He has been able to turn his success at sevens into a selection to the <a href="United%20States%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">United States National Rugby Union Team</a> for the 2010 <a href="Churchill%20Cup">Churchill Cup</a>.
